an3.61:1.1.pli: “Tīṇimāni, bhikkhave, titthāyatanāni yāni paṇḍitehi samanuyuñjiyamānāni samanugāhiyamānāni samanubhāsiyamānāni parampi gantvā akiriyāya saṇṭhahanti.
an3.61:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these three sectarian tenets—as pursued, pressed, and grilled by the astute—when taken to their conclusion, end with inaction.

an3.61:1.3.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
an3.61:1.3.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

an3.61:1.4.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetū’ti.
an3.61:1.4.eng: ‘Everything this individual person experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.’

an3.61:1.5.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
an3.61:1.5.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

an3.61:1.6.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ issaranimmānahetū’ti.
an3.61:1.6.eng: ‘Everything this individual person experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of God Almighty’s creation.’

an3.61:1.7.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
an3.61:1.7.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

an3.61:1.8.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ ahetuappaccayā’ti.
an3.61:1.8.eng: ‘Everything this individual person experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—has no cause or reason.’

an3.61:2.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
an3.61:2.1.eng: Regarding this, I went up to the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

an3.61:2.2.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetū’ti, tyāhaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadāmi:
an3.61:2.2.eng: everything an individual person experiences is because of past deeds, and I said to them:

an3.61:2.3.eng: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’

an3.61:2.4.pli: “yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ pubbekatahetū”’ti?

an3.61:2.5.pli: Te ca me evaṃ puṭṭhā ‘āmā’ti paṭijānanti.

an3.61:2.7.pli: ‘tenahāyasmanto pāṇātipātino bhavissanti pubbekatahetu, adinnādāyino bhavissanti pubbekatahetu, abrahmacārino bhavissanti pubbekatahetu, musāvādino bhavissanti pubbekatahetu, pisuṇavācā bhavissanti pubbekatahetu, pharusavācā bhavissanti pubbekatahetu, samphappalāpino bhavissanti pubbekatahetu, abhijjhāluno bhavissanti pubbekatahetu, byāpannacittā bhavissanti pubbekatahetu, micchādiṭṭhikā bhavissanti pubbekatahetu’.
an3.61:2.7.eng: ‘In that case, you might kill living creatures, steal, be unchaste; use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; be covetous, malicious, or have wrong view, all because of past deeds.’

an3.61:3.1.pli: Pubbekataṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, sārato paccāgacchataṃ na hoti chando vā vāyāmo vā idaṃ vā karaṇīyaṃ idaṃ vā akaraṇīyanti.
an3.61:3.1.eng: Those who believe that past deeds are the most important thing have no enthusiasm or effort, no idea that there are things that should and should not be done.

an3.61:3.2.pli: Iti karaṇīyākaraṇīye kho pana saccato thetato anupalabbhiyamāne muṭṭhassatīnaṃ anārakkhānaṃ viharataṃ na hoti paccattaṃ sahadhammiko samaṇavādo.
an3.61:3.2.eng: Not finding as a genuine fact that there are things that should and should not be done, they’re unmindful and careless, and can’t rightly be called ascetics.

an3.61:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho me, bhikkhave, tesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu evaṃvādīsu evaṃdiṭṭhīsu paṭhamo sahadhammiko niggaho hoti.
an3.61:3.3.eng: This is my first legitimate refutation of the ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view.

an3.61:4.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
an3.61:4.1.eng: Regarding this, I went up to the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

an3.61:4.2.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ issaranimmānahetū’ti, tyāhaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadāmi:
an3.61:4.2.eng: everything that an individual person experiences is because of God Almighty’s creation, and I said to them:

an3.61:4.3.eng: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’

an3.61:4.4.pli: yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ issaranimmānahetū’ti?

an3.61:4.5.pli: Te ca me evaṃ puṭṭhā ‘āmā’ti paṭijānanti.

an3.61:4.7.pli: ‘tenahāyasmanto pāṇātipātino bhavissanti issaranimmānahetu, adinnādāyino bhavissanti issaranimmānahetu, abrahmacārino bhavissanti issaranimmānahetu, musāvādino bhavissanti issaranimmānahetu, pisuṇavācā bhavissanti issaranimmānahetu, pharusavācā bhavissanti issaranimmānahetu, samphappalāpino bhavissanti issaranimmānahetu, abhijjhāluno bhavissanti issaranimmānahetu, byāpannacittā bhavissanti issaranimmānahetu, micchādiṭṭhikā bhavissanti issaranimmānahetu’.
an3.61:4.7.eng: ‘In that case, you might kill living creatures, steal, be unchaste; use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; be covetous, malicious, or have wrong view, all because of God Almighty’s creation.’

an3.61:5.1.pli: Issaranimmānaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, sārato paccāgacchataṃ na hoti chando vā vāyāmo vā idaṃ vā karaṇīyaṃ idaṃ vā akaraṇīyanti.
an3.61:5.1.eng: Those who believe that God Almighty’s creative power is the most important thing have no enthusiasm, no effort, no idea that there are things that should and should not be done.

an3.61:5.2.pli: Iti karaṇīyākaraṇīye kho pana saccato thetato anupalabbhiyamāne muṭṭhassatīnaṃ anārakkhānaṃ viharataṃ na hoti paccattaṃ sahadhammiko samaṇavādo.
an3.61:5.2.eng: Not finding as a genuine fact that there are things that should and should not be done, they’re unmindful and careless, and can’t rightly be called ascetics.

an3.61:5.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho me, bhikkhave, tesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu evaṃvādīsu evaṃdiṭṭhīsu dutiyo sahadhammiko niggaho hoti.
an3.61:5.3.eng: This is my second legitimate refutation of the ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view.

an3.61:6.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
an3.61:6.1.eng: Regarding this, I went up to the ascetics and brahmins whose view is that

an3.61:6.2.pli: ‘yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ ahetuappaccayā’ti, tyāhaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadāmi:
an3.61:6.2.eng: everything that an individual person experiences has no cause or reason, and I said to them:

an3.61:6.3.eng: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’

an3.61:6.4.pli: yaṃ kiñcāyaṃ purisapuggalo paṭisaṃvedeti sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā sabbaṃ taṃ ahetuappaccayā’ti?

an3.61:6.5.pli: Te ca me evaṃ puṭṭhā ‘āmā’ti paṭijānanti.

an3.61:6.7.pli: ‘tenahāyasmanto pāṇātipātino bhavissanti ahetuappaccayā …pe… micchādiṭṭhikā bhavissanti ahetuappaccayā’”.
an3.61:6.7.eng: ‘In that case, you might kill living creatures, steal, be unchaste; use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; be covetous, malicious, or have wrong view, all without cause or reason.’

an3.61:7.1.pli: Ahetuappaccayaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, sārato paccāgacchataṃ na hoti chando vā vāyāmo vā idaṃ vā karaṇīyaṃ idaṃ vā akaraṇīyanti.
an3.61:7.1.eng: Those who believe that the absence of cause or reason is the most important thing have no enthusiasm, no effort, no idea that there are things that should and should not be done.

an3.61:7.2.pli: Iti karaṇīyākaraṇīye kho pana saccato thetato anupalabbhiyamāne muṭṭhassatīnaṃ anārakkhānaṃ viharataṃ na hoti paccattaṃ sahadhammiko samaṇavādo.
an3.61:7.2.eng: Not finding as a genuine fact that there are things that should and should not be done, they’re unmindful and careless, and can’t rightly be called ascetics.

an3.61:7.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho me, bhikkhave, tesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu evaṃvādīsu evaṃdiṭṭhīsu tatiyo sahadhammiko niggaho hoti.
an3.61:7.3.eng: This is my third legitimate refutation of the ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view.

an3.61:8.1.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi titthāyatanāni yāni paṇḍitehi samanuyuñjiyamānāni samanugāhiyamānāni samanubhāsiyamānāni parampi gantvā akiriyāya saṇṭhahanti.
an3.61:8.1.eng: These are the three sectarian tenets—as pursued, pressed, and grilled by the astute—which, when taken to their conclusion, end with inaction.

an3.61:9.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an3.61:9.1.eng: But the Dhamma that I’ve taught is irrefutable, uncorrupted, beyond reproach, and not scorned by sensible ascetics and brahmins.

an3.61:9.2.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi?
an3.61:9.2.eng: What is the Dhamma that I’ve taught?

an3.61:9.3.pli: Imā cha dhātuyoti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an3.61:9.3.eng: ‘These are the six elements’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught …

an3.61:9.4.pli: Imāni cha phassāyatanānīti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an3.61:9.4.eng: ‘These are the six fields of contact’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught …

an3.61:9.5.pli: Ime aṭṭhārasa manopavicārāti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an3.61:9.5.eng: ‘These are the eighteen mental preoccupations’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught …

an3.61:9.6.pli: Imāni cattāri ariyasaccānīti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an3.61:9.6.eng: ‘These are the four noble truths’: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught that is irrefutable, uncorrupted, beyond reproach, and is not scorned by sensible ascetics and brahmins.

an3.61:10.1.pli: Imā cha dhātuyoti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhīti.
an3.61:10.1.eng: ‘“These are the six elements”: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught …’

an3.61:10.3.eng: but why did I say it?

an3.61:10.5.pli: pathavīdhātu, āpodhātu, tejodhātu, vāyodhātu, ākāsadhātu, viññāṇadhātu.
an3.61:10.5.eng: the elements of earth, water, fire, air, space, and consciousness.

an3.61:10.6.pli: Imā cha dhātuyoti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhīti.
an3.61:10.6.eng: ‘“These are the six elements”: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught …’

an3.61:10.7.pli: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an3.61:10.7.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an3.61:11.1.pli: Imāni cha phassāyatanānīti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhīti.
an3.61:11.1.eng: ‘“These are the six fields of contact”: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught …’

an3.61:11.3.eng: but why did I say it?

an3.61:11.4.eng: There are these six fields of contact:

an3.61:11.5.pli: cakkhu phassāyatanaṃ, sotaṃ phassāyatanaṃ, ghānaṃ phassāyatanaṃ, jivhā phassāyatanaṃ, kāyo phassāyatanaṃ, mano phassāyatanaṃ.
an3.61:11.5.eng: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind contact.

an3.61:11.6.pli: Imāni cha phassāyatanānīti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhīti.
an3.61:11.6.eng: ‘“These are the six fields of contact”: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught …’

an3.61:11.7.pli: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an3.61:11.7.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an3.61:12.1.pli: Ime aṭṭhārasa manopavicārāti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhīti.
an3.61:12.1.eng: ‘“These are the eighteen mental preoccupations”: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught …’

an3.61:12.3.eng: but why did I say it?

an3.61:12.4.pli: Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā somanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati domanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati upekkhāṭṭhāniyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicarati,
an3.61:12.4.eng: Seeing a sight with the eye, one is preoccupied with a sight that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity.

an3.61:12.5.eng: Hearing a sound with the ear …

an3.61:12.6.eng: Smelling an odor with the nose …

an3.61:12.7.eng: Tasting a flavor with the tongue …

an3.61:12.8.eng: Feeling a touch with the body …

an3.61:12.9.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya somanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati domanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati upekkhāṭṭhāniyaṃ dhammaṃ upavicarati.
an3.61:12.9.eng: Becoming conscious of an idea with the mind, one is preoccupied with an idea that’s a basis for happiness or sadness or equanimity.

an3.61:12.10.pli: Ime aṭṭhārasa manopavicārāti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhīti.
an3.61:12.10.eng: ‘“These are the eighteen mental preoccupations”: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught …’

an3.61:12.11.pli: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca vuttaṃ.
an3.61:12.11.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.

an3.61:13.1.pli: Imāni cattāri ariyasaccānīti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhīti.
an3.61:13.1.eng: ‘“These are the four noble truths”: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught …’

an3.61:13.3.eng: but why did I say it?

an3.61:13.4.pli: Channaṃ, bhikkhave, dhātūnaṃ upādāya gabbhassāvakkanti hoti;
an3.61:13.4.eng: Supported by the six elements, an embryo is conceived.

an3.61:13.5.pli: okkantiyā sati nāmarūpaṃ, nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanaṃ, saḷāyatanapaccayā phasso, phassapaccayā vedanā.
an3.61:13.5.eng: When it is conceived, there are name and form. Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields. The six sense fields are requirements for contact. Contact is a requirement for feeling.

an3.61:13.6.pli: Vediyamānassa kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, idaṃ dukkhanti paññapemi, ayaṃ dukkhasamudayoti paññapemi, ayaṃ dukkhanirodhoti paññapemi, ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti paññapemi.
an3.61:13.6.eng: It’s for one who feels that I declare: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an3.61:14.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of suffering?

an3.61:14.2.pli: Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, (…) maraṇampi dukkhaṃ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi dukkhā, appiyehi sampayogo dukkho, piyehi vippayogo dukkho, yampicchaṃ na labhati tampi dukkhaṃ. Saṅkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā.
an3.61:14.2.eng: Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; being coupled with the disliked is suffering; separation from the liked is suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.

an3.61:14.3.eng: This is called the noble truth of suffering.

an3.61:15.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering?

an3.61:15.2.eng: Ignorance is a requirement for choices.

an3.61:15.3.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness.

an3.61:15.4.eng: Consciousness is a requirement for name and form.

an3.61:15.5.eng: Name and form are requirements for the six sense fields.

an3.61:15.6.eng: The six sense fields are requirements for contact.

an3.61:15.7.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

an3.61:15.8.eng: Feeling is a requirement for craving.

an3.61:15.9.eng: Craving is a requirement for grasping.

an3.61:15.10.eng: Grasping is a requirement for continued existence.

an3.61:15.11.eng: Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth.

an3.61:15.12.eng: Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

an3.61:15.13.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

an3.61:15.14.eng: This is called the noble truth of the origin of suffering.

an3.61:16.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering?

an3.61:16.2.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease.

an3.61:16.4.eng: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.

an3.61:16.5.eng: When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.

an3.61:16.6.eng: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases.

an3.61:16.10.eng: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.

an3.61:16.11.eng: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.

an3.61:16.12.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

an3.61:16.13.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.

an3.61:16.14.eng: This is called the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.

an3.61:17.1.eng: And what is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering?

an3.61:17.2.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

an3.61:17.3.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
an3.61:17.3.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an3.61:17.4.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ.
an3.61:17.4.eng: This is called the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

an3.61:17.5.pli: ‘Imāni cattāri ariyasaccānī’ti, bhikkhave, mayā dhammo desito aniggahito asaṅkiliṭṭho anupavajjo appaṭikuṭṭho samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhīti.
an3.61:17.5.eng: ‘“These are the four noble truths”: this is the Dhamma I’ve taught that is irrefutable, uncorrupted, beyond reproach, and is not scorned by sensible ascetics and brahmins.’

an3.61:17.6.pli: Iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ idametaṃ paṭicca vuttan”ti.
an3.61:17.6.eng: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.”

an3.62:1.1.pli: “Tīṇimāni, bhikkhave, amātāputtikāni bhayānīti assutavā puthujjano bhāsati.
an3.62:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, an unlearned ordinary person speaks of three perils that tear mothers and children apart.

an3.62:1.3.pli: Hoti so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṃ mahāaggiḍāho vuṭṭhāti.
an3.62:1.3.eng: There comes a time when a great fire flares up,

an3.62:1.4.pli: Mahāaggiḍāhe kho pana, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhite tena gāmāpi ḍayhanti nigamāpi ḍayhanti nagarāpi ḍayhanti.
an3.62:1.4.eng: and it burns villages, towns, and cities.

an3.62:1.5.pli: Gāmesupi ḍayhamānesu nigamesupi ḍayhamānesu nagaresupi ḍayhamānesu tattha mātāpi puttaṃ nappaṭilabhati, puttopi mātaraṃ nappaṭilabhati.
an3.62:1.5.eng: When this happens, a mother can’t find her child, and a child can’t find their mother.

an3.62:1.6.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ amātāputtikaṃ bhayanti assutavā puthujjano bhāsati.
an3.62:1.6.eng: This is the first peril that tears mothers and children apart.

an3.62:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, hoti so samayo yaṃ mahāmegho vuṭṭhāti.
an3.62:2.1.eng: Furthermore, there comes a time when a great storm gathers,

an3.62:2.2.pli: Mahāmeghe kho pana, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhite mahāudakavāhako sañjāyati.
an3.62:2.2.eng: and it unleashes a mighty flood

an3.62:2.3.pli: Mahāudakavāhake kho pana, bhikkhave, sañjāyante tena gāmāpi vuyhanti nigamāpi vuyhanti nagarāpi vuyhanti.
an3.62:2.3.eng: that sweeps away villages, towns, and cities.

an3.62:2.4.pli: Gāmesupi vuyhamānesu nigamesupi vuyhamānesu nagaresupi vuyhamānesu tattha mātāpi puttaṃ nappaṭilabhati, puttopi mātaraṃ nappaṭilabhati.
an3.62:2.4.eng: When this happens, a mother can’t find her child, and a child can’t find their mother.

an3.62:2.5.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ amātāputtikaṃ bhayanti assutavā puthujjano bhāsati.
an3.62:2.5.eng: This is the second peril that tears mothers and children apart.

an3.62:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, hoti so samayo yaṃ bhayaṃ hoti aṭavisaṅkopo, cakkasamāruḷhā jānapadā pariyāyanti.
an3.62:3.1.eng: Furthermore, there comes a time of peril due to turmoil in the wilds, so the countryfolk mount their vehicles and flee everywhere.

an3.62:3.2.pli: Bhaye kho pana, bhikkhave, sati aṭavisaṅkope cakkasamāruḷhesu jānapadesu pariyāyantesu tattha mātāpi puttaṃ nappaṭilabhati, puttopi mātaraṃ nappaṭilabhati.
an3.62:3.2.eng: When this happens, a mother can’t find her child, and a child can’t find their mother.

an3.62:3.3.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ amātāputtikaṃ bhayanti assutavā puthujjano bhāsati.
an3.62:3.3.eng: This is the third peril that tears mothers and children apart.

an3.62:3.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi amātāputtikāni bhayānīti assutavā puthujjano bhāsati.
an3.62:3.4.eng: These are the three perils an unlearned ordinary person speaks of that tear mothers and children apart.

an3.62:4.1.pli: Tāni kho panimāni, bhikkhave, tīṇi samātāputtikāniyeva bhayāni amātāputtikāni bhayānīti assutavā puthujjano bhāsati.
an3.62:4.1.eng: Mendicants, an unlearned ordinary person speaks of three perils that don’t tear mothers and children apart.

an3.62:4.3.pli: Hoti so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṃ mahāaggiḍāho vuṭṭhāti.
an3.62:4.3.eng: There comes a time when a great fire flares up,

an3.62:4.4.pli: Mahāaggiḍāhe kho pana, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhite tena gāmāpi ḍayhanti nigamāpi ḍayhanti nagarāpi ḍayhanti.
an3.62:4.4.eng: and it burns villages, towns, and cities.

an3.62:4.5.pli: Gāmesupi ḍayhamānesu nigamesupi ḍayhamānesu nagaresupi ḍayhamānesu hoti so samayo yaṃ kadāci karahaci mātāpi puttaṃ paṭilabhati, puttopi mātaraṃ paṭilabhati.
an3.62:4.5.eng: When this happens, sometimes a mother can find her child, and a child can find their mother.

an3.62:4.6.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ samātāputtikaṃyeva bhayaṃ amātāputtikaṃ bhayanti assutavā puthujjano bhāsati.
an3.62:4.6.eng: This is the first peril that doesn’t tear mothers and children apart.

an3.62:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, hoti so samayo yaṃ mahāmegho vuṭṭhāti.
an3.62:5.1.eng: Furthermore, there comes a time when a great storm gathers,

an3.62:5.2.pli: Mahāmeghe kho pana, bhikkhave, vuṭṭhite mahāudakavāhako sañjāyati.
an3.62:5.2.eng: and it unleashes a mighty flood

an3.62:5.3.pli: Mahāudakavāhake kho pana, bhikkhave, sañjāte tena gāmāpi vuyhanti nigamāpi vuyhanti nagarāpi vuyhanti.
an3.62:5.3.eng: that sweeps away villages, towns, and cities.

an3.62:5.4.pli: Gāmesupi vuyhamānesu nigamesupi vuyhamānesu nagaresupi vuyhamānesu hoti so samayo yaṃ kadāci karahaci mātāpi puttaṃ paṭilabhati, puttopi mātaraṃ paṭilabhati.
an3.62:5.4.eng: When this happens, sometimes a mother can find her child, and a child can find their mother.

an3.62:5.5.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ samātāputtikaṃyeva bhayaṃ amātāputtikaṃ bhayanti assutavā puthujjano bhāsati.
an3.62:5.5.eng: This is the second peril that doesn’t tear mothers and children apart.

an3.62:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, hoti so samayo yaṃ bhayaṃ hoti aṭavisaṅkopo, cakkasamāruḷhā jānapadā pariyāyanti.
an3.62:6.1.eng: Furthermore, there comes a time of peril due to turmoil in the wilds, so the countryfolk mount their vehicles and flee everywhere.

an3.62:6.2.pli: Bhaye kho pana, bhikkhave, sati aṭavisaṅkope cakkasamāruḷhesu jānapadesu pariyāyantesu hoti so samayo yaṃ kadāci karahaci mātāpi puttaṃ paṭilabhati, puttopi mātaraṃ paṭilabhati.
an3.62:6.2.eng: When this happens, sometimes a mother can find her child, and a child can find their mother.

an3.62:6.3.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyaṃ samātāputtikaṃyeva bhayaṃ amātāputtikaṃ bhayanti assutavā puthujjano bhāsati.
an3.62:6.3.eng: This is the third peril that doesn’t tear mothers and children apart.

an3.62:6.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi samātāputtikāniyeva bhayāni amātāputtikāni bhayānīti assutavā puthujjano bhāsati.
an3.62:6.4.eng: These are the three perils an unlearned ordinary person speaks of that don’t tear mothers and children apart.

an3.62:7.1.eng: There are three perils that tear mothers and children apart.

an3.62:7.3.eng: The perils of old age, sickness, and death.

an3.62:7.4.pli: Na, bhikkhave, mātā puttaṃ jīramānaṃ evaṃ labhati:
an3.62:7.4.eng: When a child is growing old, a mother doesn’t get her wish:

an3.62:7.5.eng: ‘Let me grow old, may my child not grow old!’

an3.62:7.6.pli: putto vā pana mātaraṃ jīramānaṃ na evaṃ labhati:
an3.62:7.6.eng: When a mother is growing old, a child doesn’t get their wish:

an3.62:7.7.eng: ‘Let me grow old, may my mother not grow old!’

an3.62:8.1.pli: Na, bhikkhave, mātā puttaṃ byādhiyamānaṃ evaṃ labhati:
an3.62:8.1.eng: When a child is sick, a mother doesn’t get her wish:

an3.62:8.2.eng: ‘Let me be sick, may my child not be sick!’

an3.62:8.3.pli: putto vā pana mātaraṃ byādhiyamānaṃ na evaṃ labhati:
an3.62:8.3.eng: When a mother is sick, a child doesn’t get their wish:

an3.62:8.4.eng: ‘Let me be sick, may my mother not be sick!’

an3.62:9.1.pli: Na, bhikkhave, mātā puttaṃ mīyamānaṃ evaṃ labhati:
an3.62:9.1.eng: When a child is dying, a mother doesn’t get her wish:

an3.62:9.2.eng: ‘Let me die, may my child not die!’

an3.62:9.3.pli: putto vā pana mātaraṃ mīyamānaṃ na evaṃ labhati:
an3.62:9.3.eng: When a mother is dying, a child doesn’t get their wish:

an3.62:9.4.eng: ‘Let me die, may my mother not die!’

an3.62:9.5.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi amātāputtikāni bhayānīti.
an3.62:9.5.eng: These are the three perils that tear mothers and children apart.

an3.62:10.1.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, maggo atthi paṭipadā imesañca tiṇṇaṃ samātāputtikānaṃ bhayānaṃ imesañca tiṇṇaṃ amātāputtikānaṃ bhayānaṃ pahānāya samatikkamāya saṃvattati.
an3.62:10.1.eng: There is a path and a practice that leads to giving up and going beyond the three perils that don’t tear mothers and children apart, and the three perils that do tear mothers and children apart.

an3.62:10.2.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, maggo katamā ca paṭipadā imesañca tiṇṇaṃ samātāputtikānaṃ bhayānaṃ imesañca tiṇṇaṃ amātāputtikānaṃ bhayānaṃ pahānāya samatikkamāya saṃvattati?
an3.62:10.2.eng: What is that path and practice?

an3.62:10.3.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

an3.62:10.4.pli: sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi.
an3.62:10.4.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an3.62:10.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, maggo ayaṃ paṭipadā imesañca tiṇṇaṃ samātāputtikānaṃ bhayānaṃ imesañca tiṇṇaṃ amātāputtikānaṃ bhayānaṃ pahānāya samatikkamāya saṃvattatī”ti.
an3.62:10.5.eng: This is the path, this is the practice that leads to giving up and going beyond the three perils that don’t tear mothers and children apart, and the three perils that do tear mothers and children apart.”
